Package reference¶

  • Package reference
    • Coordinate reference systems
    • Vector package
    • Raster package

Coordinate reference systems¶

Found in karta.crs

Creates a database of CRS IDs. The CRSRegister class tracks a dictionary of CRS instances. When a new CRS is requested, it is returned from the dictionary or created on the fly.

Customized reference systems may be added at runtime as follows:

from karta.crs import crsreg

crsreg.add_CRS(“my_CRS”, proj=[projection parameters],
geod=[geod parameters], crstype=[one of ‘projected’, ‘local’, or ‘geographical’], id=[OGC URN (string)])

For example, to add a CRS for handling data in the European Terrestrial Reference System of 1989, use:

crsreg.add_CRS(“ETRS89”, proj={“proj”: “lonlat”, “towgs84”: [0,0,0,0,0,0,0]},
geod={“ellps”: “GRS80”}, crstype=”geographical”, id=”urn:ogc:def:crs:EPSG::4258”)
class karta.crs.CRS(proj=None, geod=None, crstype='unkown', id=None)[source]¶

Encapsulated a coordinate reference system.

exception karta.crs.CRSError(message='')[source]¶

Exception to raise for invalid geodetic operations.

Vector package¶

Geographical measurement and simple analysis module for Python. Provides Point, Multipoint, Line, and Polygon classes, with methods for simple measurements such as distance, area, and bearing.

class karta.vector.guppy.ConnectedMultipoint(vertices, data=None, properties=None, copy_metadata=True, **kwargs)[source]¶

Class for Multipoints in which vertices are assumed to be connected.

class karta.vector.guppy.Geometry(crs=local CRS (urn: {'urn': 'urn:ogc:def:crs:EPSG::5806'}))[source]¶

This is the abstract base class for all geometry types

add_property(name, value)[source]¶

Insert a property (name -> value) into the properties dict, raising a NameError if the property already exists. Compared to directly manipulating the properties dict, this avoids accidents.

delete_property(name)[source]¶

Equivalent to

del self.properties[name]

exception karta.vector.guppy.GuppyError(message='')[source]¶

Base class for guppy module errors.

azimuth(other, spherical=False)[source]¶

Returns the compass azimuth from self to other in radians (i.e. clockwise, with north at 0). Returns NaN if points are coincident.

coordsxy(convert_to=False)[source]¶

Returns the x,y coordinates. Convert_to may be set to ‘deg’ or ‘rad’ for convenience.

distance(other)[source]¶

Returns a distance to another Point. If the coordinate system is geographical and a third (z) coordinate exists, it is assumed to have the same units as the real-world horizontal distance (i.e. meters).

get_vertex()[source]¶

Return the Point vertex as a tuple.

greatcircle(other)[source]¶

Return the great circle distance between two geographical points.

isat(other, tol=0.001)[source]¶

Test whether point vertices are the same, regardless of properties or data. Tolarance is not geodetic.

shift(shift_vector)[source]¶

Shift point by the amount given by a vector. Operation occurs in-place

Returns the point reached when moving in a given direction for a given distance from a specified starting location.

distance (float): distance to walk direction (float): horizontal walk direction in radians

area[source]¶

Return the two-dimensional area of the polygon. If there are sub-polygons, their areas are subtracted.

contains(pt)[source]¶

Returns True if pt is inside or on the boundary of the polygon, and False otherwise. Uses a crossing number scheme.

isclockwise()[source]¶

Return whether polygon winds clockwise around its interior.

perimeter[source]¶

Return the perimeter of the polygon. If there are sub-polygons, their perimeters are added recursively.

segments[source]¶

Returns an generator of adjacent line segments. Unique to Polygon: appends a final segment to close the Polygon.

to_polyline()[source]¶

Returns a self-closing polyline. Discards sub-polygons.

to_shapefile(fstem)[source]¶

Save line to a shapefile

karta.vector.guppy.affine_matrix(mpa, mpb)[source]¶

Compute the affine transformation matrix that projects Multipoint mpa to Multipoint mpb using a least squares fit.

karta.vector.guppy.greatcircle(pta, ptb, method='vicenty')[source]¶

Computes the great circle distance between n point pairs on a sphere. Returns a list of length (n-1)

[pntlist] contains a list of point objects

[method] may be “vicenty” (default) or “haversine”. The Haversine method is roughly 20% faster, but may yield rounding errors when coordinates are antipodal.

karta.vector.guppy.points_to_multipoint(points)[source]¶

Merge points into a Multipoint instance. Point properties are stored as Multipoint data. All points must use the same CRS.

karta.vector.guppy.ray_intersection(pt, endpt1, endpt2, direction=0.0)[source]¶

Determines whether a ray intersects a line segment. If yes, returns the point of intersection. If no, return None. Input “points” should be tuples or similar. Input direction is in radians, and defines the ray path from pt.

This module includes the GeoJSON class and convenience functions for dealing with GeoJSON data. The GeoJSON class uses the builtin json module and enforces GeoJSON standards.

class karta.vector.geojson.ExtendedJSONEncoder(skipkeys=False, ensure_ascii=True, check_circular=True, allow_nan=True, sort_keys=False, indent=None, separators=None, default=None)[source]¶

Numpy-specific numbers prior to 1.9 don’t inherit from Python numeric ABCs. This class is a hack to coerce numpy values into Python types for JSON serialization.

class karta.vector.geojson.GeoJSONWriter(gpobj, linkedcrs=False, **kwargs)[source]¶

Class for converting guppy objects to GeoJSON strings. Multipoint-based opbjects are written as ‘Features’.

CRS defaults to be named. A linked CRS can be used by passing linkedcrs=True.

Does not handle ‘FeatureCollection’ types (see printFeatureCollection() function).

add_bbox(bbox=None)[source]¶

Tag the JSON object with a bounding box. If bbox is None (default), the bounds will be calculated from the data. Otherwise, bbox should be in the form (xmin, xmax, ....) for all dimensions.

add_coordinates(target=None)[source]¶

Add coordinates. Behaviour depends on the type of the geometry object. Target must be None (default) or a dictionary member of the JSON object.

add_crs(crs, linkedcrs, **kw)[source]¶

Tag the JSON object with coordinate reference system metadata using a CRS instance, which is expected the have the interface of crs.CRS.

If True, linkedcrs indicates a web-referenced linked CRS. If False, the CRS is taked to be named.

In the case of a linked CRS, the link address and type can be specified using the href and linktype keyword arguments. If not supplied, then it is assumed that crs.id[“urn”] contains the href and the type is “name”.

For more details, see the GeoJSON specification at: http://geojson.org/geojson-spec.html#coordinate-reference-system-objects

add_geometry()[source]¶

Add geometry subobject. This should be called for writing Multipoint-derived classes.

add_id(target=None)[source]¶

Add an index field.

add_properties(target=None)[source]¶

Add the data from the geometry object’s data dictionary.

print_json()[source]¶

Print GeoJSON representation.

write_json(fout)[source]¶

Dump internal dict-object to JSON using the builtin json module.

class karta.vector.gpx.GPX(f=None, waypoints=None, tracks=None, routes=None)[source]¶

Represents a GPX document, with an internal representation of waypoints, tracks, and route that loosely approximates the XML structure. Provides methods to easily add Point-like and Line-like objects as GPX types.

add_route(route)[source]¶

Add a list of Line-like objects as a route. Properties and extension types for the route are taken from the properties attribute of the Line-like object.

Properties and extensions types for each route point are taken from the data attribute of each Line-like object.

INCOMPLETE:

Needs to distinguish between properties and extensions at the trkseg and trkpt levels

Needs to properly add and <ele> property for Lines of rank 3

add_track(track, attributes=None)[source]¶

Add a list of Line-like objects as a track. Dictionaries of properties and extension types for the track are accepted as keyword arguments.

Properties and extension types for the track segments are taken from the properties attribute of each Line-like object.

Properties and extensions types for each track point are taken from the data attribute of each Line-like object.

INCOMPLETE:

Needs to distinguish between properties and extensions at the trkseg and trkpt levels

Needs to properly add and <ele> property for Lines of rank 3

add_waypoint(waypoint)[source]¶

Add a Point-like object as a waypoint. Properties and extension types are taken from waypoint.properties attribute.

fromfile(f)[source]¶

Read a GPX document from f, which may be a filename or a file-like object.

parse_trk(trk)[source]¶

Parse a <trk> node, updating self.tracks.

parse_wpt(wpt)[source]¶

Parse a <wpt> node, updating self.waypoints.

writefile(fnm, waypts=True, tracks=True, routes=True)[source]¶

Write GPX object to a GPX file. Writes all waypoints, tracks, and routes by default, which can be changed by changing the kwargs to False.

Convenience functions for XY(Z) tables.

karta.vector.xyfile.array2xyz(A, X, Y)[source]¶

There are a few occasions when an XYZ list is the proper data format. This function converts from an array A with coordinates defined by X and Y to a list of (x,y,z) tuples.

Vector geospatial metadata management

class karta.vector.metadata.Metadata(data, singleton=False, copydata=True)[source]¶

Class for handling collections of metadata. Data are organized similar to a Python dict, however different values must all have the same length and be of uniform type.

Data are accessed either by field name (returning the entire series for that field) for by index (returning the value within eather field at that index).

getfield(name)[source]¶

Return all values from field name.

keys()[source]¶

Return internal dictionary keys.

sub(idxs)[source]¶

Return a Metadata instance with values from idxs.

update(other)[source]¶

Extend collection in-place.

values()[source]¶

Return internal dictionary values.

Raster package¶

Classes for basic grid types

class karta.raster.grid.Grid[source]¶

Grid baseclass. Don’t use this directly except to implement subclasses. The primary attributes defined by all Grid-derived classed are _hdr and data.

clipz(bounds)[source]¶

Clip the z-range in place to bounds = [min, max].

copy()[source]¶

Return a copy.

max()[source]¶

Return the maximum non-nan in self.data.

min()[source]¶

Return the minimum non-nan in self.data.

minmax()[source]¶

Return the minimum and maximum value of data array.

class karta.raster.grid.RegularGrid(transform, Z=None, crs=None)[source]¶

Regular (structured) grid class. A RegularGrid contains a fixed number of rows and columns with a constant spacing and a scalar or vector field defined as Z.

Positions on a RegularGrid are referenced to their array indices (i,j) using an affine transform T such that

(a, b, c, d, e, f) = T

X = a + j * c + i * e Y = b + i * d + j * f

in which (a,b) defines the grid origin, (c,d) defines the resolution in the horizontal and vertical directions, and (e,f) can be used to define a rotation. In the common case of an orthogonal grid with north “up”,

e = f = 0

aaiwrite(f, reference='corner', nodata_value=-9999)[source]¶

Save internal data as an ASCII grid. Based on the ESRI standard, only isometric grids (i.e. hdr[‘dx’] == hdr[‘dy’] can be saved, otherwise GridIOError is thrown.

f : either a file-like object or a filename reference : specify a header reference (“center” | “corner”) nodata_value : specify how nans should be represented (int or float)

as_warpedgrid()[source]¶

Return a copy as a WarpedGrid instance. This is a more general grid class that has a larger memory footprint but can represent more flexible data layouts.

center_llref()[source]¶

Return the ‘lower-left’ reference in terms of a center coordinate.

coordmesh(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Alias for center_coords()

corner_llref()[source]¶

Return the ‘lower-left’ reference in terms of a center coordinate.

fill_sinks()[source]¶

Fill depressions. Use the algorithm of Wang and Liu (2006).

get_extents(reference='center')[source]¶

Return the region characteristics as a tuple (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax). reference may be center or edge.

get_indices(x, y)[source]¶

Return the column and row indices for the point nearest geographical coordinates (x, y).

get_profile(segments, resolution=10.0)[source]¶

Sample along a line defined as segments. Does not interpolate.

segments : iterable containing (x,y) pairs resolution : sample spacing

profile : ndarray

resample(dx, dy, method='nearest')[source]¶

Resample array to have spacing dx, `dy’.

dx : cell dimension, float

dy : cell dimension, float

method : interpolation method, string (‘nearest’,)

resample_griddata(dx, dy, method='nearest')[source]¶

Resample array to have spacing dx, `dy’ using scipy.griddata

dx : cell dimension, float

dy : cell dimension, float

method : interpolation method, string (‘nearest’, ‘linear’)

sample(x, y, method='nearest')[source]¶

Return the values nearest (x, y), where x and y may be equal length vectors. method may be one of nearest, linear.

sample_nearest(x, y)[source]¶

Return the value nearest to (x, y). Nearest grid center sampling scheme.

vertex_coords()[source]¶

Return the coordinates of vertices.

class karta.raster.grid.WarpedGrid(X, Y, Z)[source]¶

Warped Grid class. A WarpedGrid contains a fixed number of rows and columns and a scalar or vector field defined on the z-axis. Grid spacing is not necessarily constant.

fill_sinks()[source]¶

Fill depressions. Use the algorithm of Wang and Liu (2006).

resample(X, Y)[source]¶

Resample internal grid to the points defined by X, Y.

2D raster functions

karta.raster.raster.aspect(D, res=(30.0, 30.0))[source]¶

Return the slope aspect for each pixel. http://webhelp.esri.com/arcgisdesktop/9.2/index.cfm?TopicName=How%20Aspect%20works

karta.raster.raster.div(U, V, res=(30.0, 30.0))[source]¶

Calculate the divergence of a vector field.

karta.raster.raster.grad(D, res=(30.0, 30.0))[source]¶

Computes the gradient of potential D. Return a tuple (dx, dy).

karta.raster.raster.hillshade(D, res=(30.0, 30.0), bearing=330.0, azimuth=60.0)[source]¶

Return a hillshade raster for field D. Testing version.

karta.raster.raster.normed_vector_field(D)[source]¶

Computes a U,V vector field of potential D. Scalar components of U,V are normalized to max(|U, V|).

karta.raster.raster.pad(A, width=1, edges='all', value=0.0)[source]¶

Apply padding to a 2D array. A : array to pad width : thickness of padding edges : “all”, “left”, “right”, “top”, “bottom” *value” : 0.0, value to pad with

karta.raster.raster.peaks(n=49)[source]¶

2d peaks function of MATLAB logo fame.

karta.raster.raster.slope(D, res=(30.0, 30.0))[source]¶

Return the scalar slope at each pixel. Use the neighbourhood method. http://webhelp.esri.com/arcgisdesktop/9.2/index.cfm?TopicName=How%20Slope%20works

karta.raster.raster.viewshed(D, i, j, r=-1)[source]¶

Return the viewshed on D at (i,j).

karta.raster.raster.witch_of_agnesi(nx=100, ny=100, a=4.0)[source]¶
Return a raster field defined by the equation
8 a^3
Z = ————–
d^2 + 4 a*2

where d is the distance from the center.

Python ESRI ASCII grid driver

The primary class is AAIGrid, which can be called with a filename argument to open a grid, or can read data from a numpy array.

Written by Nat Wilson

exception karta.raster.aaigrid.AAIError(value, detail=None)[source]¶

Exceptions related to ESRI ASCII grid driver.

class karta.raster.aaigrid.AAIGrid(incoming=None, hdr=None)[source]¶

Grid object built around the ESRI ASCII Grid format.

clip(bounds)[source]¶

Clip the z-range in place to bounds = [min, max].

coordmesh(grid_registration='center')[source]¶

Return a pair of arrays containing the X and Y coordinates of the grid.

fromarray(A, hdr)[source]¶

Read data from a 2d numpy array. The hdr argument is a dictionary of header information, including:

ncols: [int] nrows: [int] cellsize: [float] nodata_value: [float] xllcenter OR xllcorner: [float] yllcenter OR yllcorner: [float]
fromfile(fnm)[source]¶

Read an existing ASCII grid file.

get_indices(x, y)[source]¶

Return the column and row indices for the point nearest geographical coordinates (x, y).

get_profile(segments, resolution=10.0)[source]¶

Sample along a line defined as segments. Does not interpolate.

segments : iterable containing (x,y) pairs resolution : sample spacing

profile : ndarray

get_region(reference='center')[source]¶

Return the region characteristics as a tuple, relative to either cell centers or the grid edges.

max()[source]¶

Return the maximum non-nan in self.data.

min()[source]¶

Return the minimum non-nan in self.data.

minmax()[source]¶

Return the minimum and maximum value of data array.

read(fnm)[source]¶

Read an existing ASCII grid file.

resample(cellsize, method='nearest')[source]¶

Resample array to have cellsize. Modify header in-place.

cellsize : cell dimension, float

method : interpolation method, string (‘nearest’, ‘linear’)

resize(te)[source]¶

Resize array to fit within extents given by te. If the new dimensions are smaller, the data is clipped. If they are larger, nan padding is added.

te : tuple of center coordinates in the form
(xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax).

Returns None.

sample(x, y)[source]¶

Return the value nearest to x, y.

toarray()[source]¶

Return a 2d array with internal data. Header information can be obtained with AAIGrid.hdr. This is just a nicer way of calling AAIGrid.data.copy().

tofile(f, reference='center')[source]¶

Save internal data to f, either a file-like object or a filename.

reference: specify a header reference
“center” | “corner”
